artists.name: E.T. Mensah
artists.description: “King of Highlife,” his big-band sound defined independence-era Ghana.

artists.name: Bola Johnson
artists.description: Playful highlife singer, mixing Yoruba rhythms with jazzy horns.

artists.name: BLO
artists.description: Rock-influenced funk trio, early signs of Afro-rock’s rise.

artists.name: Fela Kuti
artists.description: Began fusing highlife and jazz into the early Afrobeat experiments.

artists.name: Sorry Bamba
artists.description: Bridged Malian folk traditions with modern dance-band arrangements.

artists.name: Rail Band
artists.description: Legendary training ground for griot singers, mixing folk storytelling with electric instruments.

artists.name: Franco & TPOK Jazz
artists.description: Masters of rumba, whose music shaped Congo’s golden era.

artists.name: Tabu Ley Rochereau
artists.description: Elegant rumba innovator, fusing Cuban grooves with Congolese flair.

artists.name: Dr. Nico
artists.description: Guitar virtuoso whose melodic runs set rumba’s guitar standard.

artists.name: Daudi Kabaka
artists.description: Kenyan 'King of Benga,' with sharp, infectious guitar work.

artists.name: Miriam Makeba
artists.description: Voice of resistance, blending jazz and African folk for the world stage.

artists.name: Hugh Masekela
artists.description: Trumpeter mixing bebop and African rhythms, globally influential.

artists.name: Mahotella Queens
artists.description: Female vocal trio formed in the mid-60s, fronting mbaqanga groups with harmonies and energy that kept township jive thriving.

artists.name: Abdullah Ibrahim / Dollar Brand
artists.description: Cape jazz pianist weaving spiritual, melodic improvisations.

artists.name: Ngozi Family
artists.description: Proto-Zamrock pioneers, fuzzed-out rock with African grooves.

artists.name: Mulatu Astatke
artists.description: Father of Ethio-jazz, blending Ethiopian scales with jazz and funk.
